theory_assignments.reasoning: This theory focuses on temporal scaling of aging dynamics and lifespan distributions, emphasizing a systemic rate constant governing aging progression, fitting the temporal scaling mechanistic theme.
It describes aging as a fixed trajectory modulated by a rate constant, with lifespan changes manifesting as time axis scaling, matching the temporal scaling mechanism.
This theory integrates life history and molecular aging through temporal scaling of development, reproduction, and aging, fitting the temporal scaling theme.
It proposes evolutionary ontogenetic regulatory changes that scale somatic growth and aging rates across species, consistent with temporal scaling of developmental and aging processes.
This theory links developmental rate causally to adult lifespan, emphasizing developmental timing and programming effects on aging, fitting a developmental rate-longevity mechanistic cluster.
It highlights pleiotropic genetic effects linking development and aging, and trade-offs between growth rate and lifespan, consistent with developmental rate influencing longevity.
This theory describes aging as a programmed sequence of gene regulation phases extending development, linking gene regulation timing to lifespan, fitting developmental rate and longevity.
It emphasizes genetic regulation of aging rate linked to developmental timing and biosenescent processes, with slowed development increasing longevity, matching developmental rate and longevity.

This theory views aging as a genetically programmed continuum of development and maturation, with species-specific lifespan determined by genetic regulation, consistent with developmental rate and longevity.
It conceptualizes aging as a software design flaw in the developmental genetic program, with species differences explained by developmental pace, fitting developmental rate and longevity.
This theory proposes aging as a consequence of continued somatic remodeling (developmental inertia) beyond maturity, linking ongoing developmental processes to aging progression.
It focuses on continuity of gene expression regulation from development into aging, with miRNAs and TFs modulating gene expression trajectories, fitting a gene regulation continuity theme.
This theory highlights conserved epigenetic remodeling of developmental gene networks as a fundamental aging mechanism, supporting continuity of developmental regulation into aging.
It proposes aging driven by decay of developmental signaling pathways and derepression of p16INK4a, integrating multiple developmental pathways in aging regulation.
This theory links genetic and epigenetic drift in developmental programs to aging, implicating developmental signaling pathways like Hedgehog and Wnt in aging mechanisms.
DevAge posits aging as a developmental program active throughout life, with shared molecular pathways between development and aging, fitting gene regulation continuity.
It views development and aging as a continuum with early life programming influencing lifelong aging trajectories, emphasizing gene regulatory and epigenetic mechanisms.
This theory emphasizes developmental plasticity, embryonic senescence, and genetic/epigenetic drift disrupting developmental programs leading to aging, fitting gene regulation continuity.
It focuses on developmental programming of aging via mitochondrial dysfunction caused by early life nutrient restriction, linking mitochondrial deficits to accelerated aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Gene Repression Loss Cellular Senescence Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: This theory explains cellular senescence by stochastic loss of repressor gene copies leading to inhibitor gene expression and cell cycle arrest, a distinct gene repression loss mechanism.
